newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian trade sees aluminium up on falling stocks.
newsitem.headline: Asian trade sees aluminium up on falling stocks.

text.p: Far East base metal traders said three-month aluminium prices on the London Metal Exchange (LME) were expected to rise later on Thursday due to expectations that stocks will fall further.
Three-month aluminium was quoted at US$1,656/60 a tonne at 0560 GMT, compared with the close on the LME on Wednesday of $1,654/59 a tonne. Asian trade remained thin, dealers said.
"A very bullish close and further gains are expected in the near term. Next resistance is seen at $1,670 and then $1,680," LME brokers Brandeis said in its daily review.
LME aluminium stocks reached 785,925 tonnes on Wednesday, down nearly 54,000 tonnes from the level of 839,850 tonnes early last month.
Borrowing of nearby dates resulted in the cash/threes spread narrowing to $23/$25 by the end of Wednesday's LME kerb, against a $29 contango on the previous day.
Aluminium prices on the Tokyo Commodity Exchange (TOCOM) rose on Thursday in line with overnight gains on the LME.
TOCOM's April aluminium contract rose slightly in thin trading to 208.2 yen per kg at 0500 GMT, up 0.4 yen from Wednesday's close of 207.8 yen.
"The aluminium market was very quiet today. Prices were up due to the strong overnight close of the LME," said a trader at Japanese broker Okato Shoji Co Ltd.

Meanwhile, three-month zinc prices were also expected to breach its recent resistance level of $1,300 a tonne in the next few days, but there was a gap between $1,270 and $1,273 which needs to be filled, Brandeis said.
Broker Macquarie said zinc stocks had fallen by 75,000 tonnes so far this year and it remained confident a fall of 250,000-300,000 tonnes for the year as a whole remained likely.
"After the current consolidation period, which could last to mid-year, prices should move sharply higher," Macquarie said.
Three-month copper prices were barely changed in Asian trade as the red metal was supported by recent increases in stocks, dealers said.
